executive_summary: Companies in this industry manufacture marble products for construction, renovation and landscaping. Businesses benefited from high wages and low unemployment, as it caused aggregate private investment to swell. Higher private investment enabled companies to spend more on nonresidential construction, boosting downstream demand for the industry. Private investment fell during the COVID-19 pandemic, which depressed revenue in 2020. Manufacturers still benefited from low interest rates during the pandemic, as it accelerated housing starts and encouraged spending on home improvement. Rates have risen in recent years as the Federal Reserve has been combatting inflation, causing demand for housing to dwindle and reducing a revenue stream for manufacturers. The appreciating US dollar has also constrained exports, creating more challenges for manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Climbing Housing Starts and Private Spending on Home Improvements Boosted Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During the pandemic, housing starts accelerated as people rushed out of metropolitan areas and into suburbs as they looked to distance themselves from others. This boosted demand for marble products, as this material is used to construct countertops and flooring. Also, as people spent more time at home, they were encouraged to invest in home improvements. Per capita disposable income rose, which prompted this investing spree, including the implementation of marble products as people looked to repair or embellish their homes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Interest Rates Put a Halt to Investments
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic recovery caused supply chain disruptions, leading to significant inflation in 2022. To address rising prices, the Federal Reserve has been increasing interest rates. This has caused borrowing costs to surge, making purchasing homes or undertaking home improvements more expensive. Consequently, there has been a decline in demand for marble products, which has limited revenue growth in the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Weakened International Trade Poses a Threat to Companies
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic caused imports and exports to halt and supply chain issues have kept trade volumes relatively low. This has reduced the number of products manufacturers can ship to other countries, reducing business revenue streams. The US dollar has also appreciated, which has made domestically produced goods more expensive to foreign buyers, reducing exports and sales for manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Steadily Rising Incomes Will Boost Aggregate Private Investment
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite economic challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic, elevated inflation, soaring interest rates and recessionary fears, the industry will perform well through the end of 2028. As the economy expands, incomes steadily mount, spurring consumer spending. More consumer spending will encourage private spending on home improvements. Also, accelerating aggregate private investment will lead companies to invest in nonresidential projects, raising the need for marble products and benefiting the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Housing Market Will Recover as Households Adjust to Higher Rates
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Interest rates are expected to remain elevated, but households will adjust by changing their saving and spending patterns. Once households and individuals accumulate enough savings to purchase property again, the housing market will recover. As homebuying increases, demand for mineral products will creep upward, enhancing revenue for marble manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Implementation of Advanced Machinery and Automation Will Increase Productivity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Machines and tools are being developed to enhance cutting, shaping and polishing techniques to improve the quality of the final products. Digital technology empowers producers to direct extensive quality control checks, guaranteeing consistency and limiting defects. New technology will provide unique and complex designs and customized marble products. This will allow marble producers to compete with substitutes by offering more appealing designs.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry manufacture marble products for construction, renovation and landscaping.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - steady

key_trends: Operators benefited from record-low interest rates during the pandemic
The pandemic recovery has disrupted supply chains
Per capita disposable income incentivizes spending on home improvements
Interest rates are expected to remain elevated through 2028
Housing starts will recover as people adjust to higher rates
Marble product manufacturers will adopt better products to compete more effectively with substitutes
Rates have risen as the Federal Reserve has been combatting inflation, causing demand for housing to dwindle and reducing revenue for manufacturers

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households often purchase marble countertops, marble flooring and other marble fixtures when renovating a room in a house.
Corporations often purchase marble fixtures, countertops and flooring when renovating an office space.
Companies often purchase marble fixtures, countertops and flooring when buying a new office space.

products_and_services.product_description: Many households purchase marble countertops because the rock makes furniture seem more aesthetic. These countertops are often used in kitchens to store food on them or in bathrooms surrounding a sink.

Households, corporations and organizations purchase marble flooring because it has an upscale appearance and adds value to real estate. Installing marble flooring can sometimes be risky, as it scratches and stains easily.
Marble is also used for monuments, to decorate and cover the pillars of a building, for tomb symbols and can be used as a scrubbing agent in bathrooms.

tier_2_suppliers: Industrial Building Construction in the US
Mining, Oil & Gas Machinery Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Marble countertops, flooring and other fixtures are fairly expensive, so high-income households often purchase them. As per capita disposable income increases, more consumers can afford to buy marble products, so revenue for the industry rises.

Low interest rates boost downstream demand for manufacturers since they encourage home buying. More housing starts and residential construction raise demand for materials such as marble countertops such as marble flooring, benefiting the industry. Rising consumer spending also helps marble product makers, as it boosts business investment, enabling nonresidential construction to rise. Since offices and other nonresidential structures purchase marble fixtures, more nonresidential construction raises revenue for manufacturers.
Exchange rates affect the competitiveness of exports. The world price of crude oil impacts transportation costs for marble products.

international_trade_points.trade_description: As mass vaccination caused the economy to open up, a surge in consumer spending led to higher spending on home improvements and private investment. Since companies and households wanted to purchase and renovate their living and office space, they sought to buy marble products from various sources, so imports soared in 2021. As low-income countries become more developed, manufacturers within these countries have been producing marble and lower costs than in the United States. This is demonstrated by the share of imports from India rising significantly. Lower costs are appealing to US construction companies, so sales for domestic marble product producers have been under threat from foreign manufacturers.

The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) has encouraged closer relationships with Canada and Mexico. Canada and Mexico are significant importers of domestically produced mineral products, given their high population and extensive construction markets. The COVID-19 Pandemic Caused Exports to Plummet. State and local governments shut down businesses to stop the spread of COVID-19, so corporations stopped building and renovating homes and office space, causing exports of marble products to plunge. Restrictions on trade also made it more difficult to transport goods, which constrained exports.

business_locations.location_description: Households are moving to states in the Southwest (e.g., Texas, Arizona) in record numbers. As more individuals have moved to this region, demand for housing has risen. Consumers often purchase marble countertops, marble flooring and other marble fixtures when renovating a new home, so spending on marble products has soared in the Southwest as demand for housing has increased. Marble product manufacturers have a significant presence in this region because of the strong housing market.

The Mid-Atlantic region, specifically the New York Metropolitan area, contains the country's largest private equity firms, investment banks and stock exchanges. Many of these corporations continuously buy and build office spaces, so they often purchase marble products. Manufacturers have located in the Mid-Atlantic to capture this stream of demand.

The Southeast region contains states including Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and Virginia. These states are large, so the region has the highest share of the country's population. The large population increases the number of homes and businesses, so residential and nonresidential construction are both high in the Southeast. Businesses and households demand marble products in construction activities, so many establishments are located in this region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: This law requires that companies comply with limits on the emission of pollutants. This rule applies to marble product manufacturers because the process of finding and extracting marble can pollute the air. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) applies allowances for the level of sulfur, nitrogen oxides, ozone and other pollutants companies can release into the atmosphere.

This act ensures that marble product manufacturers don't pollute bodies of water. Since making marble products can create waste, companies might pollute streams of water if there isn't government regulation.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FAIR PACKAGING AND LABELING ACT OF 1967
regulations_points.regulation_description: This law directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to issue regulations requiring that all "consumer commodities" be labeled to disclose the net contents, the identity of the commodity and the name and place of business of the product's manufacturer or distributor. Since consumers use marble products, they're subject to this act.

OSHA is a federal agency that enforces safety and health legislation in the United States. The agency ensures that workers are adequately trained when operating in an unsafe environment. They also require manufacturers to offer employees generous workers' compensation when injured.
To ensure that COVID-19 didn't spread, governments forced manufacturers to enforce social distancing and mask-wearing laws. Marble product makers had to adjust their procedures to follow these rules.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Many states require a manufacturing license with light restrictions like proof of residence, no criminal record, and paying a fee.
Manufacturers need to purchase expensive machinery, assembly lines and pay high labor wages, making initial capital costs high.
Making marble products requires skilled labor, so manufacturers must pay very high wages, a significant barrier to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: With many small players, price is an integral factor in determining revenue as buyers have many options.
Good product quality enables companies to establish reputation and gain loyal customers for long-term revenue.
Building niche markets with loyal customers interested in specific products gives an upper hand over competitors.
High external competition from alternative materials like porcelain, limestone, laminate and imports.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Prevalence of localized, niche markets with loyal customers hinders consolidation by larger players.
Modest barriers limit fragmentation as many potential entrants cannot overcome start-up costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Passing on Costs to Maximize Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As housing starts accelerated, demand for marble products swelled as more homes were equipped with marble countertops and flooring. Despite rising prices of raw materials and crude oil, companies expanded their profits as they were able to pass on these costs to consumers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE ABILITY TO PASS ON HIGH PRICES KEEPS PURCHASE COSTS LEVEL
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2023, purchases are projected to comprise 42.3% of revenue. Purchases include the cost of buying raw materials like blocks or slabs of marble, equipment and machinery, tools, energy for operations and transporting costs. Inflation has caused the prices of many of these inputs to accelerate, but manufacturers have been able to pass on high prices to their buyers, as construction companies need these raw materials for their projects. This has kept purchase costs as a percentage of revenue steady.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: DEPRECIATION HOLDS STEADY IN RECENT YEARS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation is anticipated to make up 2.4% of revenue in 2023. Depreciation includes investment in machinery, equipment, vehicles, buildings and computers. Investment in new technology and repairs of existing machinery are similar every year, so depreciation has been stable as a percentage of revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Marble product manufacturers display a low level of capital intensity. Capital expenditures include tools, manufacturing machinery, computers and vehicles. These fabrication machines and equipment are needed for cutting and finishing marble, requiring skilled workers. Even though companies require quarrying equipment and substantial infrastructure, marble producers are only partially reliant on capital since their work is labor-intensive and not mass-produced. In 2023, mineral product manufacturers are anticipated to spend $0.09 on capital for every $1.00 spent on wages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changing raw material costs causes uncertainty
volatility_points.volatility_description: Manufacturers of marble products are directly affected by fluctuations in raw marble blocks or slab prices. Rising raw material costs can reduce profit and raise production costs, impacting the industry's profitability. It can be challenging for manufacturers to effectively plan production and pricing strategies when raw material prices fluctuate, causing uncertainty.

volatility_points.volatility_title: ECONOMIC CONDITIONS HEAVILY INFLUENCE THE INDUSTRY
volatility_points.volatility_description: The interest rate determines how expensive it is to purchase a home, with higher interest rates making them less affordable. If rates are higher, fewer people buy new or existing homes, so marble product manufacturers have fewer projects to work on since their products are used extensively in home building and designs. Interest rates have soared and declined as the Federal Reserve has responded to various economic crises, fostering significant company volatility.

Marble product manufacturers benefit when the value of the US dollar is low, as it makes domestically produced goods seem less expensive for foreign buyers, boosting exports. Exchange rates have fluctuated drastically because of interest rates, inflation and cross-country private investment, increasing revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technological disruption is low to non-existent as the introduction of new machines and software has helped rather than hindered the manufacturing of marble products. New technology may change the cost composition of

Increased automation and software have resulted in significant technological change for marble product manufacturers. Computer-Aided Design and Manufacturing (CAD/CAM) software enables manufacturers to create very precise digital designs for marble products. This gives makers of marble countertops, flooring and other fixtures effective blueprints to follow. Robotics has made its way into the marble manufacturing process, as robots can do repetitive tasks. One example of the increased use of robotics is the introduction of CNC machines, which use computer-controlled movements to cut, shape and polish marble with precision. These machines eliminate the need for labor in many areas, threatening workers in this industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The adoption and integration of software such as the Internet of Things (IoT) boosts productivity.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Since all devices and sensors are connected in one big system, manufacturers can monitor and optimize production processes in real time, increasing productivity and raising revenue.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Companies' sales heavily depend on construction, which follows trends in the general economy.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like India and Italy impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: India and Italy are the top sources of imports for this industry's products.

FAQs.question: Have you considered setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: A large portion of establishments are located in the Southeast, which has lower wages than other regions.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers are investing in more advanced tools to provide higher-quality marble products.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Through investment in automation, companies in this industry are anticipated to slow wage growth rates while increasing revenue.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies invest in R&D to develop new products that meet or exceed environmental standards.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: In 2023, profit is expected to make up 6.8% of revenue.

FAQs.question: How do high commodity prices affect your company?
FAQs.answer: High commodity prices make it more expensive to transport goods and make mineral products, damaging revenue for operators.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? Is your technical expertise to a world standard?
FAQs.answer: Use automated procedures and processes. More advanced technology enables product manufacturers to increase worker productivity and reduce labor expenses.

FAQs.question: What measures do you have in place to reduce operational costs? Are you considering any new cost-saving measures?
FAQs.answer: Develop effective cost controls. Effective cost controls increase profit for marble product manufacturers in a very price-competitive environment. The pandemic has caused highly volatile input prices for companies, which has increased profit as manufacturers were able to pass down costs to customers.

FAQs.question: Is your company involved in international trade? What impact does the trade-weighted index have on your company?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) represents the value of the US dollar relative to foreign currencies. When the TWI increases, mineral products become more expensive internationally, reducing exports and revenue.

FAQs.question: How does the level of new housing starts impact your industry? Do you expect there to be a large shift in the future?
FAQs.answer: The level of new housing starts directly impacts the manufacturing of marble products because it reflects the construction industry's demand for marble products. If there are significant shifts in the dynamics of the housing market, like consumer preferences or government policies influencing housing construction, there could be a substantial shift in the future.

FAQs.question: How has the price of oil influenced demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers of marble products face increased production costs due to higher oil prices, which could result in higher prices for their products. As consumers look for cheaper alternatives, this may result in a decrease in demand.
